text:
Those of you who create content briefs for writers:

What format do you use? Gdoc? Spreadsheet? Notes in an email?

We’re revamping our content briefs/outline templates for writers. Currently we use spreadsheets (we’re SEOs, we live and breathe in sheets), but I’m finding it’s easier in some cases to just write up a Gdoc outline.

elements.text:
Those of you who create content briefs for writers:

What format do you use? Gdoc? Spreadsheet? Notes in an email?

We’re revamping our content briefs/outline templates for writers. Currently we use spreadsheets (we’re SEOs, we live and breathe in sheets), but I’m finding it’s easier in some cases to just write up a Gdoc outline.

text: Spreadsheets! Though I’ve heard from some of our writers they prefer a breakdown in Gdoc.

elements.text: Spreadsheets! Though I’ve heard from some of our writers they prefer a breakdown in Gdoc.

text:
Gdocs for us. Writers have tended to be more comfortable in Gdocs vs spreadsheet.

It may depend on what type of info you want in your content brief though. Is it mostly keyword-related info?

elements.text:
Gdocs for us. Writers have tended to be more comfortable in Gdocs vs spreadsheet.

It may depend on what type of info you want in your content brief though. Is it mostly keyword-related info?

text: We use both Google Docs and Google Sheets. The doc is for the more descriptive stuff and outlining, and we try to limit it to 1 page. The spreadsheet is for keywords, volume, slugs, etc.

elements.text: We use both Google Docs and Google Sheets. The doc is for the more descriptive stuff and outlining, and we try to limit it to 1 page. The spreadsheet is for keywords, volume, slugs, etc.

text: I use Google Docs. They’re flexible enough to easily include a few different kinds of info in briefs. I like to provide a brief overview of the purpose of the article, include keywords in a table, outline sections I expect to see included, some some competitor research and some notes on existing content to reference/link to.

elements.text: I use Google Docs. They’re flexible enough to easily include a few different kinds of info in briefs. I like to provide a brief overview of the purpose of the article, include keywords in a table, outline sections I expect to see included, some some competitor research and some notes on existing content to reference/link to.

text: <@UPY7WN4LW> as David said, it's practical and very focused on how to create content that attracts qualified audiences and converts people into customers, rather than just being content marketing/SEO 101 like some courses are (hence the slightly more expensive cost). There are modules on how to come up with ideas, how to measure it, how to find + manage writers, promotion etc. Check out their blog content and you'll get an idea of the approach they take to content.

text:
I'd say gdocs. You can easily add a table with the keywords that the writer has to target, and it's genuinely easier when you have to write an explanation. 

You can basically do the article structure in a doc, explain what you want and let them just write the content. It's also much easier to track changes in the doc.

text:
If you’re small, I would also recommend Google Sheets. I’ve never found a template that does what I need it to do, so I always make my own.

If you’re bigger (like mid-market to enterprise) and you’ll have a large team managing the budget with you, you might want to investigate Allocadia.

elements.text:

If you’re bigger (like mid-market to enterprise) and you’ll have a large team managing the budget with you, you might want to investigate Allocadia.

text: Hi all, an unemployment question for anyone who has experience with that. The deal is, I was laid off in April. And in May I began doing freelance work. One client is paying me hourly and the other is paying by the project. I just got paid by both for the work I’d done in May. I’ve been collecting Mass. unemployment benefits since I got laid off. But now that I have paychecks in hand from the client work, I’m going to submit an unemployment claim and within that I’ll indicate how many hours I worked last week and how much income I received for this work. Does that sound like the right way to go? Another option is I can just “decline” benefits for last week. Thoughts?

elements.text: Hi all, an unemployment question for anyone who has experience with that. The deal is, I was laid off in April. And in May I began doing freelance work. One client is paying me hourly and the other is paying by the project. I just got paid by both for the work I’d done in May. I’ve been collecting Mass. unemployment benefits since I got laid off. But now that I have paychecks in hand from the client work, I’m going to submit an unemployment claim and within that I’ll indicate how many hours I worked last week and how much income I received for this work. Does that sound like the right way to go? Another option is I can just “decline” benefits for last week. Thoughts?

text: This is probably going to vary state by state. I would still file if your freelance income is less than your previous income, but submit those hours. That way if your freelance pipeline dries up, you're not up the creek with no paddle.

elements.text: This is probably going to vary state by state. I would still file if your freelance income is less than your previous income, but submit those hours. That way if your freelance pipeline dries up, you're not up the creek with no paddle.

text: <@U014FMGRKQA> Thanks Sam. Good advice! And great community!!!

elements.text: Thanks Sam. Good advice! And great community!!!

text:
I've had to create my own. The key is to create separate fields for estimated and actual with a formula that tracks the difference.

For instance, when tracking monthly freelance budget, I would have a table for each freelancer and a row for the weeks of the month. I would then estimate the hours and budget for each week. At the end of the month, I'd enter the actuals from their invoices. The formulas I created would then help me calculate if I was over or under budget.

This basic concept took different shapes depending on the budget.

elements.text:

At the end of the month, I'd enter the actuals from their invoices. The formulas I created would then help me calculate if I was over or under budget.

text: Hi Jeff - I'm also doing this in Mass. Based on my understanding, you would want to file the hours worked/$ earned per week (even if you're getting the money in one lump sum at the end of the month). This actually helps in that you can make up to a certain % of your income while still collecting UI (I believe it's around 25% for MA). Then anything you make over that amount is deducted from your weekly benefits.

elements.text: Hi Jeff - I'm also doing this in Mass. text: Yeah Jeff I’m seconding <@U015HB9LWG4>. I’m in WI. You gotta claim it as you’re going along. Take the sum you’ll be paid, break it down by week and hours worked and claim it. Not doing so has some serious repercussions! If you are guaranteed payment, you need to claim it.

text: <@UPY7WN4LW> Oh, that’s cool! For the course, I paid the 1$ 7-day trial and completed it during that time. I can’t honestly say whether the degree is worth the money as I’m not familiar with the content, but generally I like what CXL produces.
